[[Russell Fraser]] (1983-1991) |office3 = Minister of Environment and Parks of [[Executive Council of British Columbia|British Columbia]] |premier3 = [[Bill Vander Zalm]] |term_start3 = November 6, 1986 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ejae-Ia6n4AC&pg=PA107&dq=Stephen+Rogers+Canada+Conservative+Social+Credit&hl=en&ei=OSIlTf-pKcaAlAeChc3nAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q&f=false Taking the Air: Ideas and Change in Canada's National Parks] Kopas, Paul Sheldon, pg. 107 |term_end3 = March 3, 1987 |predecessor3 = [[Forbes Charles Austin Pelton]] |successor3 = [[William Bruce Strachan]] |office4 = Minister of Intergovernmental Relations of [[Executive Council of British Columbia|British Columbia]] |premier4 = [[Bill Vander Zalm]] |term_start4 = March 3 |term_end4 = November 13, 1987 |predecessor4 = [[William Bruce Strachan]] |successor4 = |office5 = Minister of State, Nechako of [[Executive Council of British Columbia|British Columbia]] |premier5 = [[Bill Vander Zalm]] |term_start5 = October 22, 1987 |term_end5 = July 6, 1988 |predecessor5 = |successor5 = |office6 = Minister of Transportation and Highways of [[Executive Council of British Columbia|British Columbia]] |premier6 = [[Bill Vander Zalm]] |term_start6 = November 13, 1987 |term_end6 = July 6, 1988 |predecessor6 = [[Clifford Charles Michael]] |successor6 = [[Thomas Neil Vant]] | party = [[British Columbia Social Credit Party|Social Credit]] | occupation = Pilot }} '''Charles Stephen Rogers''' (born March 28, 1942) was a [[British Columbia]] politician and cabinet minister from 1975 to 1991. Rogers ran for the leadership of the [[British Columbia Social Credit Party]] in the 1986 leadership race, but lost to [[Bill Vander Zalm]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wy5mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Kn8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1459,1972505 |title=Two ministers quit B.C. jobs |newspaper=[[Calgary Herald]] |date=August 6, 1986 |page=5 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} He was born in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], the son of Forrest Rogers and Gwynneth Thomas, and was educated in [[Vernon, British Columbia|Vernon]] and Vancouver. In 1967, Rogers married Margaret Wallace.{{cite book |title=Canadian Parliamentary Guide, 1986 |last=Normandin |first=P G |year=1986}} He married his second wife Valerie Richards in 1991.Stephen has four childrenâ€”two from both marriages. He was elected as a Social Credit [[Legislative Assembly of British Columbia|MLA]] in [[Vancouver South (provincial electoral district)|Vancouver South]] in [[British Columbia general election, 1975|1975]], [[British Columbia general election, 1979|1979]], [[British Columbia general election, 1983|1983]] and [[British Columbia general election, 1986|1986]]. His career culminated in serving as [[Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia|Speaker]] until 1991 when he returned to his career as an airline pilot with [[Air Canada]]. He retired from Air Canada in 2002.{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/mini/election2006/candidates/59033_CON.html |publisher=CTV |title=Election 2006 |accessdate=2012-02-15 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} Rogers was forced to resign from the position of Minister of Energy, Mines and Petroleum Resources in 1986 after it was disclosed that he was in a [[conflict of interest]] position involving a personal tax shelter investment.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yXdkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=F38NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1476,462284 |title=Conflict issue snares second B.C. minister |newspaper=[[Calgary Herald]] |date=January 22, 1986 |page=5 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} He resigned as Minister of Health later that same year just before he was charged with failure to disclose financial holdings as required by law.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nYJWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=V0ENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1244,2985025 |title=Former minister pleads guilty to not disclosing finances |newspaper=Leader-Post |location=Regina |date=April 12, 1986 |page=11 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} In 1987, Rogers resigned as Minister of the Environment following conflict of interest allegations related to a change in boundaries for [[Strathcona Provincial Park]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kO5VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dOEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4715,680538 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |title=Environment Minister Resigns |date=March 4, 1987 |page=9 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} He ran as the [[Conservative Party of Canada]] candidate for the riding of [[Vancouver Quadra]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 2004|2004 election]] and again in [[Canadian federal election, 2006|2006]], losing both times to Liberal [[Stephen Owen (politician)|Stephen Owen]].{{cite web |url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/About/Parliament/FederalRidingsHistory/hfer.asp?Include=Y&Language=E&rid=763&Search=Det |title=Vancouver Quadra, British Columbia (1947 - ) |work=History of Federal Ridings since 1867 |publisher=Parliament of Canada |accessdate=2012-02-15}} Rogers is a lifelong resident of Vancouver. ==References== {{Vander Zalm Ministry}} {{Bill Bennett Ministry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rogers, Stephen}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Air Canada people]] [[Category:British Columbia Social Credit Party MLAs]] [[Category:Canadian aviators]] [[Category:Conservative Party of Canada candidates in the 2004 Canadian federal election]] [[Category:Conservative Party of Canada candidates in the 2006 Canadian federal election]] [[Category:Members of the Executive Council of British Columbia]] [[Category:Politicians from Vancouver]] [[Category:Speakers of the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian politicians]] [[Category:Commercial aviators]]
